steps.title: â€œOnly in Ohioâ€ is a joke on social media that pokes fun at Ohio.
steps.content: â€œOnly in Ohioâ€ is a joke on social media that pokes fun at Ohio. The meme is often used to caption over-the-top, absurd, or unfortunate images or videos (commonly featuring apocalyptic situations) to imply that these situations could only happen in a place as bizarre or strange as Ohio. Not that Ohio is especially strange in reality, but itâ€™s fun to single out the state for a laughâ€”likely because nothing much happens there in the first place. Example: On November 21, 2022, TikTok user @ryzwtf posted a video featuring a carnival ride comically slingshotting its riders into the air with the caption, â€œOnly in OhioğŸ’€â€

steps.title: â€œOhio vs. the Worldâ€ is a meme that imagines Ohio taking over the planet.
steps.content: â€œOhio vs. the Worldâ€ is a meme that imagines Ohio taking over the planet. This version of the Ohio memes sets up Ohio as some sort of malevolent force trying for world domination, usually with fake news headlines saying things like â€œOhio took over America,â€ or, â€œOhio is invading Canada,â€ as well as other goofy scenarios. Example: One popular Ohio vs. the World meme features an MS-paint drawing of 2 astronauts looking at an Earth that only features one big Ohio. â€œWait, itâ€™s all Ohio?â€ one astronaut says. The other, pointing a gun at the first, says, â€œAlways has been.â€ [1] X Research source

steps.title: â€œCanâ€™t even X in Ohioâ€ is used to caption inconvenient situations.
steps.content: â€œCanâ€™t even X in Ohioâ€ is used to caption inconvenient situations. This is a twist on the older â€œCanâ€™t have sh*t in Detroitâ€ meme. Itâ€™s a tongue-in-cheek way to complain about common frustrations, or even absurd, surreal, or fictional conundrums, usually accompanied by the song â€œSwag Like Ohioâ€ by rapper Lil B. The meme is meant to imply that Ohio has supernaturally bad vibes, or that itâ€™s a place where bad things just tend to happenâ€”though of course the joke has little real-life basis. Example: TikToker @fwkairu posted a video on August 18, 2022, featuring an enormous animated spider crawling across the moon, captioned, â€œcanâ€™t even look at the moon in ohioğŸ’€â€

steps.title: The Ohio memes started with an image posted to Tumblr in 2016.
steps.content: The Ohio memes started with an image posted to Tumblr in 2016. On August 6 that year, popular Tumblr account screenshotsofdespair posted an image of a digital bus stop sign that, for some reason, read, â€œOhio will be eliminated.â€ [2] X Research source The post quickly took off, with over 100,000 notes, and people started riffing with their own jokes about the exaggerated dangers and shortcomings of Ohio. Some time later, a Reddit user by the name of chutotkaa posted a map of the United States labeled â€œDANGER PRESENTED BY OHIOâ€ featuring color-coded â€œOhio advisoriesâ€ in surrounding states.

steps.title: The memes found their way to TikTok in August 2022.
steps.content: The memes found their way to TikTok in August 2022. The meme popped up on TikTok when user @redie999 uploaded a video featuring a CG creature prowling by his window with the caption â€œIâ€™m just trying to sleep in OhioğŸ’€,â€ with â€œSwag Like Ohioâ€ by Lil B playing over it. After, users began uploading similar videos with the sound, and the rest is history. [3] X Research source Since then, people like to make up apocalyptic, horrific, or absurd situations and claim they happen â€œonly in Ohio.â€ In 2023, YouTuber CG5 uploaded a song inspired by the meme, which people like to poke fun at, because Ohio memes in general are fun to poke fun at. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Ohioâ€™s just a random, mundane target, which makes the memes funnier.
steps.content: Ohioâ€™s just a random, mundane target, which makes the memes funnier. Thereâ€™s a lot of answers to this question, but maybe the best answer is just that Ohio is a little boring. Itâ€™s a midwestern state where nothing much happens, and so pretending that itâ€™s the epicenter of the apocalypse, a rogue state bent on world domination, or just someplace with terrible vibes is that much funnier. Some say itâ€™s also because Ohio is emblematic of American capitalist, suburban culture, so the memes are actually a sort of parody or social commentary, romanticizing or dramatizing the â€œmidwest wasteland.â€

steps.title: Use â€œOnly in Ohioâ€ to caption surreal or unfortunate images and videos.
steps.content: Use â€œOnly in Ohioâ€ to caption surreal or unfortunate images and videos. One of the best parts about the memes is how versatile they are! If you see something even mildly strange, be it a video of a dog walking menacingly on its hind legs, or a clip from the latest Godzilla movie, caption or comment something like, â€œOnly in Ohioâ€ or, â€œCanâ€™t even take a walk outside in Ohioâ€ to get in a good-humored jab at everyoneâ€™s favorite midwestern punching bag.

steps.title: Canâ€™t have sh*t in Detroit
steps.content: Canâ€™t have sh*t in Detroit This is the origin of the â€œCanâ€™t have X in Ohioâ€ memes, and it used to caption unfortunate circumstancesâ€”a joke about Detroitâ€™s notoriously low standard of living. It started when a Facebook user posted an image of a house missing its front steps, captioned â€œSomeone stole my f--king porch . I opened my door an fell ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸ u can't have shit in Detroit"â€ [5] X Research source Fun fact: The original post was actually made about Cincinnati, Ohio, but was edited to say Detroit. It all comes full circle.

steps.title: Ohio Final Boss
steps.content: Ohio Final Boss This refers to Japanese TikTok user Saoyu0704, or just â€œSatoyu.â€ Satoyu is known for parodying anime protagonists, but became associated with the Ohio memes because he always says â€œOhayoâ€ during his streams (which is just Japanese for â€œGood Morningâ€). Now, people joke that heâ€™s the â€œFinal Boss of Ohio,â€ given his tendency to imitate popular, intimidating anime characters.
